comments.commentBody: Didn't Ayn Rand accept either Medicaid or Medicare at the end of her life?

suefitzgerald:

You may not be aware that Ryan (a Janesville, Wisconsin native) comes from a family that owns some major construction companies, including companies that have made LOTS of money doing construction for PUBLIC entities.

link:
http://www.ryancentral.com/
http://www.ryanfl.com/

Ryan saved the Social Security Survivor's Benefit money that he got when his father died when Ryan was 16. He used that to help pay for college. He apparently didn't need it to live on, so it went into the piggy bank.

Ryan got his, and as far as he is concerned, the rest of society can look out for itself. That's who Paul Ryan is.

Well, now, let's be real for a second. Would you or anyone else have read an article entitled "Paul Ryan, Charlie Rosner"? That's why ledes exist.

Interestingly, as it turns out, the VISTA part of the story is actually the more interesting element, and by far the most ironic, seeing as it is connected to the Great Society, something totally anathema to Ryan and ilk.

You just like most conservatives ignore the Greek national pastime which is tax evasion.

It is the wealthy in Greece who are the biggest tax cheats. Just like the current crop of wealthy Americans whose incomes are from dividends, capital gains, and deferred gains, which while legal here, still allow them to pay far less in percentage than the ordinary citizen.

Even the costs of their tax attorneys are deductible, and those attorneys are influential in writing the tax codes.

Re: "Rand was an atheist, and not a particularly moral one. "

Ayn Rand (I've read her pretty thoroughly) utterly rejected not just the supernatural stuff in Judeo-Christianity, but also the ethical foundation--completely. Ryan, an enthusiastic follower of Rand, simply ignores Rand's atheism and professes himself a Roman Catholic. What this means is that Ryan accepts the supernatural stuff in Judeo-Christianity but, like Rand, utterly rejects the ethical foundation.

By conventional standards of morality Rand and Ryan are not just "not particularly moral"; they are avidly and enthusiastically immoral.
great rightwing propaganda.

Walter said:

"There is no way on God's green earth that the American taxpayer can take care of the millions of middle class workers, the hundred million lower class workers and the indigents--as these people don't have the money, they don't get medical care and that is simple logic."

Walter, baby, most of us have worked ALL of our lives. I am a senior citizen, and I have always taken care of myself, and I am STILL a middle class worker. I am a TAXPAYER and I VOTE.

Thank ya' all for insulting me and millions just like me. (Did I say that with the right accent?)

Ain't NO WAY Romney and Ryan get my vote.

Obama/Biden 2012

Paul Ryan's "solution" is to let the poor starve or die of untreated medical conditions, and use the money saved in the process to give tax cuts to millionaires. The more media attention his budget gets, the more scary it will seem to voters.

This is very reminiscent of McCain's choice of Sarah Palin as his running mate. She wilted under serious scrutiny, and Ryan will do the same.
It comes down to how many people read the NY Times versus how many get their "news" from Fox.

Thank you so much for defining what Romney & Ryan are planning for us.

I sincerely hope that you are wealthy enough to take care of your future (full of unkowns). Medical care can wipe out entire life savings for most, even with medical insurance. I hope you know that.

I hope you have enough savings to last a life time when you are old and no longer 'productive', when R&R have deprived you of social security and medicare.

Walter, I wish you well with no malice in my heart, unlike yours.
Stockholm Syndrome?

Anna, the farm bill is mainly a give-away to big agri-business. Small farmers benefit very little, but the politicians that support the farm bill want to give it the image of helping the small, struggling farmer.
However, the drought in the Midwest may cause some of the farmers to adjust their belief in global climate change, now that it is affecting their pocketbooks.

As pointed out in this article there are a lot of reasons for white people who traditionally vote Republican to stop doing so.

I was reading an article today about how unhappy Republican voting farmers are with the Republican dominated congress for not passing a farm relief bill. The farmers are suffering catastrophic crop losses because of a serious drought caused by climate change and the climate change denying Republicans have resisted passing legislation to ease their burden. I wonder how long these farmers will continue to support the Republican party.

A non-wealthy individual in this country who votes for a Republican votes against his own interest.

When they say we must live within "our" means, what they're really saying is, you, middle class and poor, live within your (limited to nearly non-existant) means and we, the uber-rich, will live within our (considerable, nearly unlimited) means.

Yes, we have to "live within our means," say the smiling Republicans. Slash taxes again and again for the rich, so the "means" we---we old people needing Medicaid for long term care, young people needing Pell grants and government support for education, unemployed needing food stamps, retirees needing Social Security income to live on and Medicare if htey get sick---have to live within keeps shrinking, down to nothing, so the Ann Romneys of the world can buy more show horses, so Bain Capital can buy and loot more companies, so bank CEOs can preside over more self-enriching fraud, and on and on. I say, let's provide ourselves the means to live in a humane, enlightened society based on something more meaningful than the right of the strong to grind the weak under their heels. It would be simple to have plenty of means to live in a good society: JUST RAISE TAXES.
Palin brought huge crowds at first, too. But voters in November? Not so much.

Robert
You brought me back to the summer of '69.
Soul on Ice was required reading for all incoming freshmen at Rutgers College.
It was a book that opened an 18 year old's mind to the idea that maybe, just maybe, America was not the land of opportunity for all.
Thanks for bringing me back.

" 'The people' however are nowhere consulted, although everywhere everything is done always in their name and obstensibly for their betterment, while their real life problems go unsolved."-Eldridge Cleaver, Soul on Ice
Let's hope so. Please be sure to vote in the general election this year.
from your mouth to the goddess' ears ....

johnj702:

I just checked your blog and your comments. Typical Republican: Liars! You did not vote for Obama, you even liked Bush...This is your comment from 2010

"Yo, listen up. W was doing fine tilll the Dems got in. Check it out. The economy didn't nosedive till they took control. Poor Obama.....................” You even liked Christine O'Donnell...isn't she the nutty one from your area?
Paul Ryan is a pathetic "Tea-Bagger" who cannot even add a column of numbers correctly in the Federal budget.  He will go down in flames along with "Mitt the Twit"!

The real issue in this campaign is not any particular budget. it's about how we spend our money, and how we fund the government. it's about priorities and allocation of resources.

The real issue is whether we want to structure American society to make the country great, or continue with silly policies where we end up with the socioeconomic structure of a third world country.

unfortunately, another real issue is that we cannot afford to be great while heading towards being a third world country.
N ot a fan.

kmp, "cutting the older generation off of the dole ?" I think not. SS and Medicare are not welfare programs. I have paid large sums of money into these government programs, and I expect my government to fulfill its end of the bargain.

Generational warfare is just one more divide and conquer strategy. The "under 55" provision in Ryan's plan is aimed squarely at Gen X: I am one of the last of the boomers, born in 58, and it hits me. But it doesn't hit the majority of boomers. Gen X always has hated the boomers (I understand that) but its yourselves you will be hurting.

We all must hang together or we will hang separately.

I can appreciate the significant danger of taking on the burden of health care for the aging Boomers.  As a Gen X-er myself, like Ryan, this concerns me to no end and cutting the older generation off of the dole might make financial sense,  but, I'm always astounds keep that the Christian-centric GOP would turn their backs on the teachings of the Bible (e.g. Matthew 25:45 or Genesis 41:34).  Instead they spend the bulk of the Christian teaching harping on who is fornication with whom (and for some people, wanting to watch it in exchange for his tax dollars).

It's not so great to be a poor child now either.  We're still one of the richest countries in the world--although the way so many people talk, you'd never know it--but in some states up to 24 percent of the children live in poverty.  Not only are they growing up in poor families, but we are making it more and more difficult for them to get a decent education with our refusal to provide adequate funding.

Perhaps what this debate really needs right now is a high-quality documentary or other exposé about what is was like to be elderly in the United States prior to social security and medicare/medicaid. It wasn't pretty. And it wasn't so great to be a poor child back then, either, when your health plan was essentially reliant on prayer and the whims of nature. (Horatio Alger was fiction, just like Ayn Rand, so don't even try to go there.) Still, today, our welfare and entitlement system ain't much, but it's enough to survive and maintain dignity.

There are practical, reasonable, sensible ways to reform these programs without destroying them and starting over. The system is not perfect, but it's worked pretty darn well for 75 years or so, and there's no reason it can't continue indefinitely if right-wing voters in this country would allow some grown-up legislators back into the halls of Congress.

Classical mob, hat was.

Disgusting.

Romney choosing Ryan as VP candidate shows the contempt he has for the American people.
Watching the cheering crowds of adoring fans of this ticket reminds me of the jeers during the primary when presented with a gay soldier and someone without insurance needing medical care. They shouted "let him die" and disrespected a soldier fighting for our country.
They should be ashamed, instead they cheer those who would take their rights away.
No, because the Ryan plan is not the Romney plan - did you watch 60 Minutes last night?

The truth?
Will romney tell everyone that under the Ryan plan he will pay no taxes, but the poor and the middle class will pay more?

Will he tell catholics that their bishops oppose the Ryan budget as heartless to the poor and middle class?

Will he tell us that defensespemding will increase to benefit the dfense industry and everyone else will suffer?

Will he tell us that the elderly will be denied health care and children will not receive milk through WIC?

Will he tell us that unemployment insurance will be severely restricted and Pell grants denied to deserving students?

Will he claim responsibility for these things and so many other actions or just claim it is business as usual
You're right, Marianne. When we speak of "entitlements," we should be speaking of the uber-rich.

http://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/11/business/in-the-superrich-clues-to-rom...

Romney and his ilk, the superrich either pay NO income tax or tax is hovering around 10-13%. (see above published by The NY Times on 8/11/12 per IRS data.)
This makes a fiscal shortfall. We, stupid middle class suckers make up for what the millionaires and billionares don't pay for.
THAT'S THE ROMNEY-RYAN PLAN AND SOME MORE!

As you are of a particular age, why not voluntarily take the cuts to Social Security and Medicare for which Ryan is calling?  It will show that you are indeed putting your money where your mouth is, although if you do, you may have less money to eat.

Of course you are "safe". So that as an easy argument for you. I'm approaching 50 and have paid into this system so YOU can have first class care for the past 25 years. However, I'm well under 55 but too old to re-jig my entire career to become either a vulture capitalist or hedge fund manager so that I actually might be able to afford health care in my old age.

Your argument would have more credence if you volunteered to go on private health insurance to relieve the burden on those of us supporting you. Otherwise it looks like an "I've got mine - let the rest of the eat cake" point of view.
Simpson Bowles was never going to pass.

I am a registered 73 year old Democrat, but I applaud Paul Ryan for his courage to put forward a plan, however, imperfect, to reform entitlements.

The effort is long overdue, and must, indeed, start with an effort to reign in the raising cost of Medicaid and Medicare.

I equally lament that the President failed to present plan of his own on how to deal with the spiraling out of control deficit.

And heartbroken that Obama ignored the recommendations of the Simpson Bowles bipartisan commission, whose balance of tax inceases and cuts was about a good as it gets.

So, kudos to Paul Ryan and I hope that the Democrats put forward a better plan than Paul Ryan's.

@ Cindy

What "social teaching" does Ryan or the present Catholic Church bring to anything: dogma, greed and avoidance and circumvention of responsibility?

The legacy of Vatican II is long defunct.

"One strength he (Ryan) brings to the ticket is a grounding in the social teaching of the Catholic Church, to which he belongs"

I am not sure what Catholicism Rep. Ryan belongs to because his savaging of the safety net

Romney and Ryan think RR stands for Rolls Royce.

How many of those does Marie Antoinette Romney drive?
